passages.text: **Schaeffler AG (SHAO** **D** **E**
CMD, self-help and humanoids... coming off the defence and upgrading to Buy/High Risk

On 16th September Schaeffler will present CMD targets for the mid-term,and provide an update on synergy/self-help actions, defence exposure and their in-house humanoid robot start-up - which we deep-dived with management in June (LINK). We think the risk-reward in the shares is attractive going into the event, with the shares offering cheap optionality to a megatrend and with bread & butter industrial/auto performance likely to improve FY26 vs 25. We upgrade to a Buy/High Risk rating, lifting our DCF based target price to €6.75.

CMD September 16th -We expect a strategy update, 2028 mid-term targets and a focus on synergy and structural drivers for the group from here, where margins are likely to be seen expanding ~100bps per annum in FY26/27 towards a mid-term Adj. EBIT potential of ~7%. We also expect some focus on defence and robotic growth drivers, where we see management as bullish. Schaeffler could become an EU champion in humanoid actuator hardware, with TAM estimates by 2050 of $1tn+.Even on low assumed market shares this could change the equity story at Schaeffler.Investor interest in the theme is high and Schaeffler appear well positioned to capitalize.

**Some** **evidence** **of** **improving** **IP** **trends,** **peers** **outperforming** -Some key peers of Schaeffler on the bearing side have rallied hard from their own lows. We understand the picture is slightly muddied at Schaeffler given e-mob losses but see improving IP trends in the US/EU as supportive for risk-reward near term, as Schaeffler moves to hedge ICE declines with BEV growth, reduce headcount and reduce net-debt from ~2.4x ND/EBITDA FY25E. We sit x% above Cons on FY26 EBIT, sensitive to assumed e-mob margins.

**Humanoid** **call-option** -We are not suddenly calling for a rapid inflection in Schaeffler's top-line on the humanoid theme, nor are we now ascribing lofty valuations to, thus far, very small humanoid revenues which remain in pre-production stage, with market shares still opaque. However, given the lack of broader LVP growth, we think Schaeffler can see decent growth in humanoids if they execute well in the next 18m. This positive headline risk, and credible products into this megatrend lead us to lift our assumed mid-term growth from 1.5% to 2.5%.
**Buy/High Risk** from Neutral / High Risk
**Catalyst Watch:Upside**
Expected share price return 21.0%
Expected dividend yield 4.5%
Expected total return 25.4%
**Price Performance**
(RIC: SHAOn.DE, BB: SHAO GR)
**Harald C Hendrikse**
**Soumava Banerjee**

Whilst pricing is likely to be deflationary over time, the volume growth potential is clearly large, led by the US, and Asia and not just in industry. Home and healthcare bots appear to be significant TAM drivers in the space on a 10Y view. We see Schaeffler as optimistic on the business prospects. We await potential financial targets for humanoids at the 2025 CMD (Sept- 25) and see higher humanoid valuations, even on small revenues, as a bull case scenario for the shares. Sizing mid- term growth from humanoids remains challenging, but, if successful, we think the business can outperform LVP on humanoid volume support, potentially taking mid- term/terminal volume growth estimates at the group level to \(\sim 2.5\% /1\%\) . We
are starting off conservative, acknowledging the technology is effectively pre-revenue, but sense investor enthusiasm that Schaeffler's exposure can grow from here.

Opening catalyst watch into September 16th CMD: Whilst the focus for investors is rightly the bread and butter industrial auto business, we think Schaeffler's exposure to humanoids is attractive in a sector context and we see the potential risk-reward as sufficiently good, both into the CMD and on a 12m view, as justifying a more positive view. There is some tentative evidence of US/EU IP trends finding a floor, with execution on self-help, the managing higher of e-mob margins and the gradual de- leveraging of the business all likely to be mid-term tailwinds for shares.

TLDR: We expect Schaeffler to provide a roadmap towards \(7\% +\) FY28 group margins, supported by e- mob being managed to breakeven levels, cost savings and synergies accelerating from 2026. This should imply we are passing trough group margins in FY25, slightly behind other Tier1 auto suppliers who are growing their respective margins in 2025 vs 2024. We expect some time to be saved for the glossier ends of the Schaeffler story i.e. Defence and Humanoids. These are not huge profit drivers in the near term, in our view, but areas of credible growth where we see the group as well positioned.

Margins below potential: Schaeffler have three divisions generating \(7\% +\) adj. EBIT margins in 2025e, with group Ex- E- mob margins at \(10.2\%\) on our estimates. This is very strong in an EU supplier context and should be viewed as relatively high quality in nature given: i) the strong cash conversion of ICE revenues, ii) the exposure to industrial end- markets with differing cycles to LVP, and iii) the exposure to the automotive aftermarket which is more stable and more profitable vs traditional Tier1 work.

E- mobility losses weighing on group performance, we see these moving towards breakeven by 2028: The key offset to group margins this year is E- mobility, where margins are guided in a \(- 17\%\) to \(- 15\%\) range, up from \(- 22.1\%\) in FY24a. This weakness reflects the integration of the Vitesco acquisition, more conservative accounting on the business, with limited R&D capitalisation, and with gross margins still below potential and sensitive to volume growth from here. Management sees e- mobility order intake as encouraging at \(1.3x\) in 2Q25, supported by ramp ups across regions and with improving volumes supporting sequentially better margins from here. Our sense is that breakeven levels for e- mobility are likely a 2028 story (we look for \(- 3.9\%\) margins FY27e), and we would expect management to confirm this at the CMD. Any acceleration of e- mob breakeven to 2027 would therefore be a positive message at the CMD alongside a credible roadmap for how the breakeven will be achieved.

B&IS: We think management will lift the lid on the various end- markets serviced by B&IS, with a special focus likely to be applied to aerospace and defence likely where we understand Schaeffler have \(\sim\) 400m revenue exposure to defence helicopters and where there is clear runway for further growth. We also anticipate an update on the strategy for wind related price deflation in China, and how B&IS margins may be managed back up towards double digit levels as we've seen in the past/

PTC: We expect management to provide a deep dive on the strategy of PTC and offer further explanation on how Schaeffler have hedged themselves against any drop- off in ICE revenues/FCFs with growth from new products. 2Q25 showed an encouraging order book momentum for HEV products at 2.6x Book- to- bill, so we would expect the company to further explain the strategy for HEV growth, how they think about ICE vs PHEV vs BEV demand in the US and how they are managing planned ramp- downs across regions on the ICE side of the business, where Book- to- bills remain below \(1.0x\) at \(0.7x\) 2Q25.

Auto industry vocally questioning CO2 rules - a potential positive theme in 2H25, relevant for PTC: In an open letter to Ursula Von der Leyen, both ACEA and CLEPA outlined their expectations heading into a September \(12^{\text{th}}\) strategic dialogue on the EU CO2 reduction framework. Schaeffler CEO of Powertrain and Chassis Matthias Zink (president of EU supplier body CLEPA) co- signed a 3 page letter (LINK) noted that "Meeting the rigid car and van CO2 targets for 2030 and 2035 is, in today's world, simply no longer feasible. Instead, the current CO2 reduction path in road transport must be recalibrated to ensure it delivers on EU climate goals whilst also safeguarding Europe's industrial competitiveness, social cohesion, and the strategic resilience of its supply chains" adding that the groups hope to "recalibrate EU policy for the automotive value chain in line with today's shifting market, geopolitical, and economic realities." Whilst Schaeffler have hedged their ICE exposure with their e- mobility business, we see any dilution to the EU CO2 framework as a positive for Schaeffler given the exposure to legacy ICE technologies and the higher margin profile of those activities today. We look for any signs of EU pragmatism on this issue as a potential positive catalyst for the industry, with Schaeffler clearly positive exposed.

VLS: We expect management to remain upbeat on the cash generation power of VLS and the overall stability of the business in a group context. With the EU fleet already old and ageing further, we think management likely expect margins to remain structurally at a mid- teens level, though we think pushing margins much beyond the current level is likely to be difficult. We think there is room to provide further evidence on why the EU aftermarket is so attractive and why VLS top- line growth is likely to remain robust from here.

Upside potential from more R&D discipline: Other Tier1 suppliers have made better progress in 1H25 in terms of reducing net investment spend across capex, expensed and capitalised R&D, with Schaeffler's investment spend rising in 1H25 vs 1H24 despite the significant industry pressure in the period from tariffs. We think there could be some giveback in the 2H from an investment perspective across the industry, with some investment reductions unsustainable and likely to dribble back in to 2H25 i.e. delayed not structurally cut. The overall narrative across the sector is that investment spend is coming down from here, but we think Schaeffler arguably has more room to catch up now. A big part of this could be driven by lower investment spend in e- mobility and PTC, where we think the group can be more aggressive from here on the R&D side. Given the low R&D capitalisation rate at Schaeffler vs peers, this could quite quickly drop to EBIT margin outcomes, which we see rising in 2026 vs 2025 at an attractive level vs peers.

story in the context of Gross/Net debt balance €7.3bn/€5.7bn and FY25e ND/EBITDA of - 2.5x.

Moving to production: Humanoid OEMs are currently pushing to ensure the software is ready, with Schaeffler moving at speed to ensure the hardware is ready for mass adoption also. The company believe we are exiting the era of prototypes and entering the era of implementation, per our recent expert call (LINK) Schaeffler looks well positioned in motion technologies, with \(>1,000\) patents registered in 2024 and with key competencies around the key areas of motion required to make humanoids work e.g. bearings and actuators.

Why Humanoids may see rapid growth: Schaeffler sees the global shortage of workers as a key driver of humanoid robotics, especially for hazardous or menial work where labour shortages arguably strain market growth. Supporting this, AI and technological advancements now mean there is an ability to scale humanoids in a workable way i.e. "the need is coinciding with the means" as David Kehr, President of Humanoid Robotics at Schaeffler phrased it.

Schaeffler as a user: The company is proactive in testing this technology with pilot programs in the group already and may stand to benefit from humanoid cost take- out on the manufacturing site, where the group have \(\sim 100\) manufacturing locations globally today. Within this, the group is targeting repetitive tasks that humans do not enjoy doing, or where it is ergonomically challenging or hazardous work e.g. working with hazardous materials, packaging/lifting and at or close to furnaces where work is unpleasant for humans.

A key growth driver is actuators: Humanoids have 30 degrees of freedom which all need an actuator to facilitate. The expert stated that Actuator component costs account for between \(35\%\) and \(50\%\) of the cost of the robot. This share may stay stable over time as there is expected to be strong deflation across hardware as the technology scales, but other costs such as battery packs and chips may also experience deflation. Hence, we cannot rule out actuator share taking a higher or lower share of total bot costs over time. It is worth noting that Schaeffler do not design and produce robots and are more of a supplier into the industry.

Manufacturing likely to lead adoption at first. Some of the first applications are likely to be in manufacturing settings. Over time the group are enthused about the opportunities in healthcare and consumer facing markets but acknowledge this may accelerate from 2030 onwards given heightened safety requirements for these types of bots.

On deflation: The company fully expect humanoid prices to come down sharply, driven by i) adoption rates and ii) standardisation. It will take time for pricing to come down to rock bottom levels and it is noted that humanoids try to use standard bearing sizes already, where Schaeffler are a manufacturer. The company expect this rapid deflation in the next 4- 5 years.

By region: The largest humanoid markets are likely to be China and the US. It is noted that the US seems to be leading on the software side, but a lot of the hardware suppliers are in China. The group see a significant opportunity in the West but note that the company have already succeeded in China on bearings and automotive and can compete in the space in Asia also.

Implications: The company expect the "Other" business to show rapid growth by the end of the decade and have an internal "sprint to 2027" targets to ensure the company have the right designs and relationships in place in the next 18m. On this, Schaeffler do not have resource to manage relationships with the \(100+\) players in the space. Some players are targeting growth in home applications first, where the bots are lower cost and quality with plastic actuators, where Schaeffler is not targeting growth currently. Schaeffler also have to consider OEM funding to ensure growth is targeted with the most stable platforms. Net net, Schaeffler believe they are working with all the major players in some capacity at this time.

Advantages of humanoids vs industrial robots: Schaeffler already have industrial robots/cobots in their factories. The benefits of humanoids are mainly in unloading/manual tasks that involve decisions that take the level of automation higher in the plant. Multi- tasking roles are better suited to humanoids in this regard. In terms of the Payback on Humanoids, the economics of humanoids vs humans are seen as attractive for repetitive or dangerous functions. One humanoid can work 3 shifts a day ( \(\sim 21\) hours) meaning one humanoid can potentially replace 3- 4 humans, again according to David Kehr, President of Humanoid Robotics at Schaeffler.

When will workable prototypes arrive? Schaeffler already have workable pilots that are doing actual work in the plants. The company is learning a lot from that experience and note that real world factors including floor surface conditions can have tangible impacts on performance, which must be addressed over time through software/machine learning etc.

Development cycles: Schaeffler noted that new humanoid versions are being developed every 6- 12m, making capital allocation a key priority at this time. A typical humanoid may have a useful life of \(\sim 3\) years, potentially rising over time with standardisation.

Lifting capacities: Current applications are not for very heavy parts. There are some heavy duty models in existence, but OEMs are working on generalist bots allowing for 50lbs of lifting capacity which is in- line with what a human is expected to be able to lift.

Long term applications: Home and healthcare are expected to be the key areas of outperformance in the long- term. The company expect manufacturing to lead in the next 5 years, with home and healthcare applications accelerating in 5 years for now, given the need for even more advanced safety features.

Key milestones: The expert noted that there is clearly a lot of hype around dancing humanoids at this time. However real World KPIs will be based on volumes and growth. The company noted that they need product in the field to gather data to improve the bots, to create better R&D versions to create better bots.

Battery Space/ Uptime: One of the most relevant considerations for OEMs is uptime based on battery life. Some OEMs are designing bots that can run for 2 hours and then recharge in 10 minutes, similar to a coffee break for a human. Some OEMs are using larger batteries potentially allowing for 4- 8 hours uptime. It is unclear what the correct formula will be at this stage. In any case packing larger batteries into the humanoids requires more energy to run the humanoid, with more expensive bearings/actuators also. Schaeffler see a variety of approaches to this topic at present.

Pilots: The company has a pilot with Hexagon (covered by Martin Wilkie) to test one of the company's new pilot humanoids "AEON". Schaeffler has also made a minority investment in 2024 in Agility Robotics, who are a leading manufacturer of bipedal Mobile Manipulation Robot (MMR).

The aftermarket: In the next 5- 8 years the company expects demand to be driven by OEM hardware. The company also expect opportunities in the aftermarket and services in fields like training and safety. The company expect aftermarket replacement actuators through various channels based on the customer/end- user. From an actuator stand- point the company see very limited failures on humanoids. The company think it is too soon to predict how long joints will last at this time, but it is acknowledged that some heavy wear and tear parts may degrade shoulder/hip joints within their expected useful life, creating an aftermarket for components over time.

Defence applications: In general, the company is delving more into defence within the group. Currently there are no planned defence applications for humanoids within the group, with the main focus being on manufacturing and industrial applications.

Next steps: We believe investors should look out for announcements of more standardized components for humanoids going into production, where OEMs allow for such disclosure. The company also expect to be showcasing their products at a number of trade fairs in the coming quarters also.

Humanoids gaining traction: Several megatrends appear to have already increased appetite for automation; the multipolarity of global trade, ageing populations, climate change, AI etc. As it relates to industrial automation, clearly a lot of work has already been done with respect to automation. Most automotive factors already feature very high levels of automation with cobots already established technology across much of the metal forming, painting, and final assembly processes. However, in terms of multi- skill automation there is clearly scope for further automation, with humanoid robots increasingly seen as the next obvious layer of automation within the plant. Some examples below:

Demographics support further automation: We note that in several key industrial markets birth rates are towards the lower end of their historic trend, with dependency ratios, i.e. the share of those outside working ages, starting to rise towards the top of the historic ranges on ageing populations. These factors, coupled with supply chain inflation, re- mapping of trade routes and increased competitive pressures in a number of end markets (e.g. in EV competitiveness), are requiring a further industrial drive for manufacturing efficiency gains. Humanoids are seen as one potential solution, with short payback cycles vs traditional employment and with good scalability across a number of other areas with skills/labour shortages e.g. in healthcare, education, entertainment and logistics.

Sizing the potential TAM: Clearly, forecasting humanoid adoption curves is subject to substantial standard error, given the market is growing from effectively zero today and given visibility on the regulatory and commercial viability of such bots are both known unknowns. However, assuming commercial viability is achieved, we would expect rapid growth in the next 5- 7 years for humanoids, led by industrial and manufacturing applications before broadening out to potential consumer applications in healthcare, the consumer market and beyond. We have built a model to forecast the potential growth in this market, which makes several assumptions around pricing, volumes and hourly running costs, with 2050 TAM estimates highly sensitive to inputs. A few points:
1. We assume in the coming years there is a rapid growth in the scaling of industrial humanoids for manufacturing roles, with volumes growing \(\sim 80\%\) CAGR through to 2030.
2. We then believe there could be an acceleration in growth as more applications in consumer facing roles become commercially viable e.g. in Healthcare and Consumer applications.

3. Throughout this period, we expect price deflation for robots to continue, with pricing falling \(-15\%\) CAGR through this decade supporting industrial humanoid costs of \(\sim \$ 12,000\) per unit by 2037, down from \(\sim \$ 75,000\) at present.
4. Following this, we expect several years of significant growth, albeit at lower CAGRs of \(\sim 30\%\) through to 2045, before gradually declining to \(\sim 10\%\) growth 2050e.

5. Our estimates would imply a 2050 annual humanoid market of \(\sim 150m\) units, with a population \(\sim 600m\) units at this time on an assumed lifecycle of \(\sim 5\) years as the industry matures.

6. With cost deflation having persisted through much of that period, our assumed 2050-unit cost of \(\sim \$ 10k\) /unit would imply a total TAM of \(\sim \$ 1.5tn\) ; a very large number though admittedly significantly less than we have seen from a number of other forecasters on the theme.

7. One these estimates, the improvement in humanoid lifecycles and reduced unit costs could support a per hour cost of humanoids as low as \(\Phi 0.85\) vs an estimated \(\Phi 9.00\) today, which admittedly could be even lower but for some assumed charging, aftermarket service, training and insurance costs we include in for completeness.

8. If we assume that \(30\%\) of the total bot cost remains attributable to actuators, and if we add on an assumed \(10\%\) of MRSP service cost for bots within their lifecycle for replacement joints, we believe the 2050 market for Humanoid actuators/services could exceed \(\Phi 600bn\)

9. If Schaeffler can even corner \(5\%\) of the humanoid actuator market, we think this could still support top-line growth at Schaeffler (from today's €24bn, up to €54bn by 2050, or \(\sim 3.3\%\) pts of organic top-line growth potential.

Valuations in the Humanoid theme are relatively rich for pure plays: We note that valuations on thematic humanoid baskets are high vs Schaeffler at \(\sim 10x\) P/BV and \(\sim 50x\) P/E, having re- rated YTD also. Obviously Schaeffler is not a pure play on this theme, and the principal driver of the shares in the mid- term is likely to remain the industrial/automotive business. However, should we see Schaeffler make progress in commercially viable humanoids we think thematic investors may be quick to re- rate the shares, something that could be announced in the next 12m- 18m. On the flip side, even if we see limited growth from humanoids over the coming 24m, the underlying business looks far from expensive to begin with, at \(8.0x\) FY26E EV/EBIT.

Schaeffler has less froth, but showcasing growth is clearly central to any re- rating: We believe management will devote some time at the CMD to address the mid- term strategy for both defence and humanoids. However, with the CMD principally focused on mid- term targets to \(\sim 2028\) , we feel confident that humanoid volumes will not be a major driver of mid- term margins/FCF at the group, instead being geared into 2030/2032 growth potential. That said, we think management will shed further colour on their product offering in the space, the growth potential for the market and some of the customers/partners the group are focused on. We think management are bullish on this theme, and we expect any
commentary around the topic to focus on i) the unique offering Schaeffler brings, and ii) the rapid growth management expect to see in the coming years.

Above LVP growth and potential for higher multiples create something of a free 'call option' at Schaeffler, with the next 18m critical to showcasing gains in the space: We think Schaeffler is likely to be very sensitive to any positive headlines around humanoids in the coming quarters, and whilst many OEMs prefer to take a private/cautious approach to such announcements, we think the volume of humanoid newsflow likely accelerates from here as OEMs have more tangible evidence of progress. In our prior forecasting we noted that if Schaeffler can even corner \(5\%\) of the humanoid actuator market, we think this could still support top- line growth at Schaeffler (from today's €24bn, up to €54bn by 2050, or \(\sim 3.3\%\) tops of organic top- line growth potential). Any evidence that the group is on this track should be taken positively.

With our overall estimates for the core divisions of Schaeffler broadly unchanged over the mid- term, we believe near- term upside in Schaeffler likely stems from improving mid- term top- line growth on any major humanoid/defence contract wins on the actuator/bearings side, coupled with self- help savings coming through. We model in \(2.5\%\) mid- term growth in our Schaeffler DCF to account for the growth potential from humanoids, appreciating this is still a very nascent theme but where we think growth from low levels is credible on a 5Y view. Our underlying WACC/Beta estimates remain conservative at \(7.2\% /1.60\) reflecting high net debt/market cap dynamics. On higher assumed mid- term growth our price target, which remains very sensitive to assumptions, rises from EUR 5.00 to EUR 6.75, supporting our upgrade to a Buy (High Risk) rating. In the context of this growth being still speculative, and in light of the necessary balance sheet repair and better e- mobility margins, we believe this justifies maintaining the High Risk element of our rating.

Opening catalyst watch into September 16th CMD: Whilst the focus for investors is rightly the bread and butter industrial auto business, we think Schaeffler exposure to humanoids is attractive in a sector context and we see risk- reward as sufficiently good, both into the CMD and on a 12m view, to warrant a more positive view. There is some tentative evidence of US/EU IP trends finding a floor, with execution on self- help, the managing higher of e- mob margins and the gradual de- leveraging of the business all likely to be mid- term tailwinds for shares.
Margins recover back towards a high single digit range on improving LVP, IP and more stable pricing trends with successful cost take out, FCF inflects
We reach our target price using a DCF and terminal value calculation, which results in a EUR 6.75.
Further LVP downside could drive a valuation de- rating for Schaeffler with FCF, ND and margins reaming at low levels.

With the Vitesco acquisition (indicated closure in Q4 2024), Schaeffler becomes one of the largest auto parts supplier with sales of \(\sim \epsilon 25bn\) . The group's key products include a range of BEV and combustion engine powertrain components including e- drive systems, chassis solutions, and engine/transmission components. The group also operates in vehicle lifetime solutions (automotive aftermarket) and in automotive bearings and industrials division.

We rate Schaeffler BUY/High Risk. We see Schaeffler as a cheap way to position for a European IP recovery and expect group margins to gradually improve from FY25 lows as e- mobility losses are managed lower over time. We continue to see shares as high- risk in the context of high \(\sim 2.5x\) ND/EBITDA and with limited FCF generation in 2025 on cash- out restructuring costs. We do however expect 2026 to be a better year for the business from a FCF generation perspective and see reduced ND as a key driver of upside in shares from here. We are also positive into the September 16th CMD where we expect an update on the transformation plan and expect management to drill into deeper details on their growth plans for defence bearings and humanoid robots, where we think investor interest is high.

We reach our target price using a DCF and terminal value calculation, which results in a EUR 6.75. We use \(2.5\%\) mid term and \(1.0\%\) terminal sales growth and \(7.0\%\) mid- term EBIT margin and \(6.0\%\) terminal EBIT margins. We use a WACC of \(\sim 7\%\) . We think mid- term growth will be contingent on better IP trends and stabilisation in global LVP volumes and China pricing, with any rapid growth in humanoid components a potential upside to mid- term revenue growth if Schaeffler can prove themselves as leaders in the actuator supply chain of this nascent industry.

We rate Schaeffler High Risk given the uncertain outlook for light vehicle production (LVP), powertrain mix, China pricing and, given the above average net debt profile for the business with Vitesco merger integration ongoing, we think Schaeffler shares will trade with a higher beta vs history.

Downside risks to our target price include: i) weaker than expected e- mobility margins on potentially impaired US EV volume assumptions, ii) prolonged EV slowdown risk presents downside risk to our thesis as volatility in the powertrain mix requires much quicker adjustments to the cost structure, iii) China risk – rising market share of pure- play BEV players may present downside risk if Schaeffler is not able to win new platforms on growing OEMs, iv) Execution risk – in particular integration of Vitesco, v) volume/price/inflation/fx and other market risks are also applicable to this investment case, vi) further price pressure in areas like wind on Chinese
competition, (vii) broader LVP downgrades could weigh on margins due to fixed cost absorption.

Upside risk to our target price include: i) SOTP valuation is appealing for the portfolio especially if we see an inflection in margins, ii) volume/price/inflation/fx and other market factors could also present upside risk to the investment case and target price, iii) Schaeffler could attract higher valuation multiples if they can execute on the humanoid supply chain opportunity, iv) Schaeffler self- help could see FY26- 28 margins in effect higher than we/consensus expect.

Citi Research stock recommendations include an investment rating and an optional risk rating to highlight high risk stocks. Risk rating takes into account both price volatility and fundamental criteria. Stocks will either have no risk rating or a High risk rating assigned.

Investment Ratings: Citi Research investment ratings are Buy, Neutral and Sell. Our ratings are a function of analyst expectations of expected total return ("ETR") and risk. ETR is the sum of the forecast price appreciation (or depreciation) plus the dividend yield for a stock within the next 12 months. The target price is based on a 12 month time horizon. The Investment rating definitions are: Buy (1) ETR of \(15\%\) or more or \(25\%\) or more for High risk stocks; and Sell (3) for negative ETR. Any covered stock not assigned a Buy or a Sell is a Neutral (2). For stocks rated Neutral (2), if an analyst believes that there are insufficient valuation drivers and/or investment catalysts to derive a positive or negative investment view, they may elect with the approval of Citi Research management not to assign a target price and, thus, not derive an ETR. Citi Research may suspend its rating and target price and assign "Rating Suspended" status for regulatory and/or internal policy reasons. Citi Research may also suspend its rating and target price and assign "Under Review" status for other exceptional circumstances (e.g. lack of information critical to the analyst's thesis, trading suspension) affecting the company and/or trading in the company's securities. In both such situations, the rating and target price will show as "—" and "–" respectively in the rating history price chart. Prior to 11 April 2022 Citi Research assigned "Under Review" status to both situations and prior to 11 Nov 2020 only in exceptional circumstances. As soon as practically possible, the analyst will publish a note re-establishing a rating and investment thesis. Investment ratings are determined by the ranges described above at the time of initiation of coverage, a change in investment and/or risk rating, or a change in target price (subject to limited management discretion). At times, the expected total returns may fall outside of these ranges because of market price movements and/or other short-term volatility or trading patterns. Such interim deviations will be permitted but will become subject to review by Research Management. Your decision to buy or sell a security should be based upon your personal investment objectives and should be made only after evaluating the stock's expected performance and risk.

Catalyst Watch/Short Term Views ("STV") Ratings Disclosure: Catalyst Watch and STV Upside/Downside calls: Citi Research may also include a Catalyst Watch or STV Upside or Downside call to indicate the analyst expects the share price to rise (fall) in absolute terms over a specified period of 30 or 90 days in reaction to one or more specific near- term catalysts or events impacting the company or the market. A Catalyst Watch will be published when Analyst confidence is high that an impact to share price will occur; it will be a STV when confidence level is moderate. A Catalyst Watch or STV Upside/Downside call will automatically expire at the end of the specified 30/90 day period. The Catalyst Watch will also be automatically removed if share price performance (calculated at market close) exceeds 15% against the direction of the call (unless over- ridden by the analyst). The analyst may also remove a Catalyst Watch or STV call prior to the end of the specified period in a published research note. A Catalyst Watch/STV Upside or Downside call may be different from and does not affect a stock's fundamental equity rating, which reflects a longer- term total absolute return expectation. For purposes of FINRA ratings- distribution- disclosure rules, a Catalyst Watch/STV Upside call corresponds to a buy recommendation and a Catalyst Watch/STV Downside call corresponds to a sell recommendation. Any stock not assigned to a Catalyst Watch Upside, Catalyst Watch Downside, STV Upside, or STV Downside call is considered Catalyst Watch/STV No View. For purposes of FINRA ratings distribution- disclosure rules, we correspond Catalyst Watch/STV No View to Hold in our ratings distribution table for our Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside rating system. However, we reiterate that we do not consider No View to be a recommendation. For all Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside calls, risk exists that the catalyst(s) and associated share- price movement will not materialize as expected.
